There are bar chairs missing under the slab fabric, which is not
              properly supporting the reinforcement into its correct position
              within the slab’s thickness.

The relevant Australian
              Standard AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings states in section
              6.4.6 Fixing of reinforcement and void formers that

‘Reinforcement and void formers shall be fixed in position
              prior to concreting by means of proprietary spacers, bar chairs
              with bases, ligatures or other appropriate fixings so as to
              achieve the required reinforcement position and concrete
              cover’
. Additionally, section 5.3.2 Reinforcement that

‘The slab mesh shall be placed towards the top of the raft
              or slab’ .

These bar chairs must be properly installed prior to any concrete
              being poured.

There had not been crack control bars installed at all of the
              re-entrant corners of this slab.

It is a requirement of section 5.3.7 Shrinkage cracking control
              of AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings, that

‘At re-entrant corners, two strips of 3-L8TM, or one strip
              of 3-L11TM or 3-N12 bar, shall be placed across the direction of
              potential cracking. All such reinforcement shall have a minimum
              length of 2 m’ .

These crack control re-entrant bars must be installed prior to
              pouring concrete.

There are areas where the slab has not been constructed as
              detailed on the engineering drawings.

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the
              designed requirements of the approved drawings prior to pouring
              concrete, or otherwise be re-designed and certified by the
              original design engineer. The building permit may also need to be
              amended by the relevant building surveyor to reflect the changes
              to the approved drawings.

The external beam has not been constructed as detailed on the
              engineering drawings.

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

              amended by the relevant building surveyor to reflect the changes
              to the approved drawings.

The steel reinforcement specified by the engineer has not been
              installed as detailed on the engineering drawings where there are
              pipes penetrating the slab fabric top mesh.

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

There is steel reinforcement specified by the engineer that has

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

The step-down in this area has not been constructed as detailed
              on the engineering drawings.

This will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect the

The steel reinforcement on the internal beam has been cut out for
              the pipe/penetration, which is now not the same strength as the
              steel detailed on the engineering drawings on the internal
              beam.

Additional splice bars will need to be installed to the internal
              beam to reflect the designed requirements of the approved drawings
              prior to pouring concrete.

There is a pipe that has a horizontal offset within the depth of
              the slab, which will become encased in concrete and not allow for
              the expected differential surface movement of the ‘P’
              class site, which may lead to the pipe cracking and leaking
              underneath the slab.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 2870 Residential Slabs and
              Footings only allows for straight vertical pipes to run through a
              slab, not offset ones, and requires any such penetration to be
              detailed to allow for this expected movement. However, it does not
              provide guidance on how to lag or treat such a penetration on a P
              class site.

The offset within this pipe should therefore be lowered down
              beneath the slab so that only a vertical pipe runs through the
              depth of it.

The 12mm reinforcement bar (N12) does not have sufficient lap in
              their joins.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 2870 Residential Slabs and
              Footings states in section 5.3.2 Reinforcement that

‘Reinforcing bars shall have a lap length at splices not
              less than 500mm up to a bar diameter of 12mm’ .

The laps to these bars will need to be rectified prior to any
              concrete being poured.

The 16mm reinforcement bar (N16) does not have sufficient lap in
              their joins.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 2870 Residential Slabs and
              Footings states in section 5.3.2 Reinforcement that

‘Reinforcing bars shall have a lap length at splices not
              less than 700mm up to a bar diameter of 16mm’ .

The laps to these bars will need to be rectified prior to any
              concrete being poured.

The slab detail on the engineering documents have not been
              completed.

This engineering detail must be properly constructed prior to any
              concrete being poured. Alternatively, the builder should provide
              the owner with revised engineering drawings and computations to
              confirm the changes. The building surveyor must also be notified
              of any engineering changes, as the building permit may need to be
              amended, and another inspection carried out by the
              surveyor’s inspector.

The reinforcing slab fabric has not been supported into its
              correct position within the slab’s thickness.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 2870 Residential Slabs and
              Footings states in section 5.3.2 Reinforcement that

‘The slab mesh shall be placed towards the top of the raft
              or slab’ .

This item will need to be rectified prior to any concrete being
              poured.

The formwork boxing has not been installed hard down onto the
              vapour barrier, which will result in concrete spill and blow out
              which in turn will increase the width of the footing and exposes
              this slab to significantly higher uplift pressure from the
              expected foundation heave.

It is our advice that the inconsistent widths of these overspills
              result in inconsistent bearing capacities along the length of the
              external walls and will be problematic as they increase the
              effective footing width in random areas. These overspills will
              also remain below the future finished ground level allowing water
              to accumulate on top of them and prevent normal evaporation drying
              of the subsoil moisture.

Overspills prevent expanding soil from sliding past the normally
              vertical edge beam and it follows that these wider areas of edge
              beams can be lifted with less soil expansion forces than the areas
              that do not have them. It must be noted that all footings in the
              BCA and AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings are shown with
              edges of their footings vertical and without overspill.

This will need to be rectified prior to any concrete being
              poured.

Only a licenced plumber is qualified to fit this sewer pipe
              connection, however the concreter is likely to install it, and
              past history has shown that in the majority of cases, without
              using PVC primer and glue, often just pushed into place as the
              concrete is being poured. Additionally, the large area of steel
              reinforcement mesh that is to be removed for this smart pan may
              not have additional support provided before concrete is
              poured.

The builder will need to provide photographic evidence to the
              owner to confirm compliant sewer connection by the licensed
              plumber.

The vapour barrier has had pickets driven through it, which will
              allow ground moisture up into the concrete floor when these
              pickets are withdrawn during the pouring process.

It is a requirement of section 5.3.3.4 Installation of AS 2870
              Residential Slabs and Footings that

‘Both vapour barriers and damp-proofing membranes shall be
              placed beneath the slab so that the bottom surface of the slab and
              beams, including internal beams, is entirely
              underlaid’
and that

‘Penetrations by pipes or plumbing fittings shall be taped
              or sealed with a close-fitting sleeve or made continuous with the
              vapour barrier or damp-proof membrane by taping or by
              lapping’ .

It is important to note that there are no other allowances within
              the mandatory section of AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings
              for any penetrations through the vapour barrier at all. Further,
              given that when these pickets are withdrawn during the pouring
              process the resulting penetrations will not be taped or sealed the
              present boxing setup will leave the bottom surface of this slab
              not entirely underlaid, resulting in it being susceptible to the
              ingress of ground moisture up into the porous concrete, along with
              the associated dampness, mould and resulting health issues
              possibly caused by this phenomenon.

Finally, as the Performance Requirements of the NCC/BCA Part
              2.2.3 Dampness require that

‘Moisture from the ground must be prevented from causing
              (a) unhealthy or dangerous conditions, or loss of amenity for
              occupants; and (b) undue dampness or deterioration of building
              elements’

, all of the present pickets must be removed from penetrating
              through the vapour barrier and the resulting punctures fully
              repaired prior to any concrete being poured.

The step-down boxing uprights will thereafter need to be properly
              supported on bar chairs or the like and securely tied into
              position with tie wire, to ensure compliance with the above.

The vapour barrier around a number of the pipe and other
              penetrations has not been properly taped and sealed to them.

It is a requirement of section 5.3.3.4 Installation of AS 2870
              Residential Slabs and Footings that

‘Penetrations by pipes or plumbing fittings shall be taped
              or sealed with a close-fitting sleeve or made continuous with the
              vapour barrier or damp-proof membrane by taping or by
              lapping’ .

All of these penetrations must be properly sealed prior to any
              concrete being poured.

There is loose waffle pod debris in areas throughout the base,
              which will reduce the effective beam sizes and minimum concrete
              cover around the steel reinforcement.

It is a requirement of section 5.3.2 Reinforcement of AS 2870
              Residential Slabs and Footings, that

‘Reinforcement in rafts and slabs shall be placed with
              minimum concrete cover of 20mm to an internal surface’ .

The waffle pod debris in these areas must be completely cleaned
              out prior to pouring concrete.

The void former waffle pods have not been properly supported
              along their front edges, and have rolled.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 2870 Residential Slabs and
              Footings states in section 6.4.6 Fixing of reinforcement and void
              formers that

‘void formers shall be fixed in position prior to
              concreting by means of proprietary spacers, bar chairs with bases,
              ligatures or other appropriate fixings so as to achieve the
              required reinforcement position and concrete cover’ .

This item will need properly rectified prior to any concrete
              being poured.

The balustrade in this area has been constructed so it is
              climbable, and the possible fall is greater than 4m.

Part 3.9.2.3 Balustrades or other Barrier Construction of the
              Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires that

‘Where it is possible to fall more than 4m, any horizontal
              elements within the barrier between 150mm and 760mm above the
              floor must not facilitate climbing (the 4m is measured from the
              floor level of the trafficable surface to the surface
              beneath)’ .

This balustrade must be immediately rectified so that it is
              installed in accordance with the requirements of the BCA.

The construction of this area appears to be different from the
              construction documents we were provided.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.03 Setting out the site states that

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has
              failed to comply with the requirements of the approved
              drawings’
, and clause 2.09 Dimensions of building elements states that

‘Deviations from the documented height or cross-sectional
              dimension of building elements such as beams and posts are
              defective if they exceed L/200 where L is the documented dimension
              or 5 mm, whichever is the greater’ .

As this discrepancy is greater than the maximum allowable
              dimensions stated above, this area must be rectified/reconstructed
              in accordance with the contract documents.

The construction of this area appears to be different from the
              construction documents we were provided.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.03 Setting out the site states that

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has
              failed to comply with the requirements of the approved
              drawings’
, and clause 2.06 Building dimensions states that

‘Departures from documented set out for external elements
              such as garages, carports, verandahs, decks, patios, etc. are
              defects if they exceed L/100 or 5 mm, whichever is the greater,
              where L is the documented dimension’ .

As this discrepancy is greater than the maximum allowable
              dimensions stated above, this area must be rectified/reconstructed
              in accordance with the contract documents.

The construction of this area appears to be different from the

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has

As this discrepancy is greater than the maximum allowable

The finished floor level (FFL) of this home appears to be
              different from the construction documents we were provided.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.07 Finished floor levels states that

‘Finished floor levels (FFL) or reduced levels (RL) are
              defective where they do not comply with specified planning and/or
              building permit requirements’
, and

‘In other cases, FFL or RL are defective where they depart
              from the documented RL or FFL by more than 40mm’ .

As lowering the finished height of this home is impossible
              without demolishing it, the builder should, confirm that the
              as-built home fits into the local planning requirements and
              amending the approved plans and building permit, otherwise it
              should be demolished and re-constructed in accordance with the
              planning and building permit documents.

The construction of this area appears to be different from the

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has

‘Departures from the documented set out for service rooms

As this discrepancy is greater than the maximum allowable

The construction of this building appears to be over the title
              boundary.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.03 Setting out the site states that

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has
              failed to comply with the requirements of the approved drawings,
              the allotment Certificate of Title, planning or development
              approval, relevant planning overlays and schemes and building
              regulations’
, and that

‘Building work must not encroach over an allotment boundary
              unless authorised/approved to do so. A builder must ensure
              footings, gutters and any other part of the building work does not
              encroach an allotment boundary’ .

This must be properly investigated and rectified/reconstructed in
              accordance with the above.

The set out of this building appears to be different from the

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and

‘A building set out is defective where the set out has

This must be properly investigated and rectified in accordance

There are visible scratches/chips in the basin that need to be
              removed.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 18.02 Faults and damage to appliances and
              fittings states that

‘Damage to appliances and fittings supplied as part of the
              building contract is defective if it is due to the builder’s
              workmanship’ .

This basin will need to be replaced or repaired in accordance
              with above.

There are visible scratches/chips in the bath that need to be
              removed.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 18.02 Faults and damage to appliances and
              fittings states that

‘Damage to appliances and fittings supplied as part of the
              building contract is defective if it is due to the builder’s
              workmanship’ .

This bath will need to be replaced or repaired in accordance with
              above.
There is visible damage in the fitting in this area.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 18.02 Faults and damage to appliances and
              fittings states that

‘Damage to appliances and fittings supplied as part of the
              building contract is defective if it is due to the builder’s
              workmanship’ .

This basin will need to be replaced or repaired in accordance
              with above.

There are visible scratches/chips in the shower base that need to
              be removed.
The Victorian Building Authority’

s Guide to Standards and Tolerances clause 18.02 Faults and
              damage to appliances and fittings states that

‘Damage to appliances and fittings supplied as part of the

There is visible damage in the shower screen.
The Victorian Building

Authority’s Guide to Standards and Tolerances clause 13.03
              Shower recess and components states that

‘Scratches in shower bases, screens and glass are defective
              if they are due to the builder’s workmanship and are visible
              from a normal viewing position’ .

This screen will need to be replaced in accordance with
              above.

There are visible scratches/dents in the sink that need to be
              removed.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 18.02 Faults and damage to appliances and
              fittings states that

‘Damage to appliances and fittings supplied as part of the
              building contract is defective if it is due to the builder’s
              workmanship’ .

This basin will need to be replaced or repaired in accordance
              with above.
This door has a step down to the ground greater than 230mm.

Part 3.9.1.6 Thresholds of the Building Code of Australia (BCA)
              states that

‘Where the threshold of a doorway is more than 230mm above
              the adjoining surface it must incorporate steps having riser and
              going dimensions in accordance with 3.9.1.2” .

The height of this threshold must be made to comply with this
              requirement of the Building Code of Australia (BCA).

There is visible evidence that the concrete has been installed
              with a time gap between supply, which has resulted in what appears
              to be cold joints in this area. These cold joints have not been
              designed or documented by the structural engineer, and may have
              implications on the structural integrity of the slab.

As a cold joint in a slab must be designed by the engineer, the
              builder should forward the engineering design and building
              surveyor’s inspection approval notice for this amendment to
              the slab.

In the absence of this documentation, the builder should demolish
              this section and reconstruct in accordance with the rectification
              design provided by the original design engineer. The owner should
              request a copy of the engineer’s rectification design and
              ensure that any work is carried out under the supervision and
              approval of the building surveyor.

The top of the floor slab has been cut/chased, which would have
              either exposed or cut away the steel reinforcement mesh from
              within it, compromising the slab’s integrity.

The builder must have the original design engineer inspect and
              make recommendations on the acceptability of these cuts to ensure
              the slab’s long-term performance. The owner should request a
              copy of the engineer’s comments and/or recommendations and
              ensure that any rectification work is carried out under the
              supervision and approval of the building surveyor.

There has been an obvious repair to the top of the finished floor
              slab.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances, clause 2.12 Repairs to Exposed Concrete Slabs states
              that

‘The repair is defective if it does not, as closely as
              practical, match the existing work in appearance, colour and
              texture’.

The finish of this exposed concrete floor will need to be
              rectified so that it is consistent in appearance, which will most
              likely require it to be re-topped (a thin concrete screed
              applied).

There are areas throughout this slab where cracks have developed
              in the concrete. These cracks are not random shrinkage cracks,
              instead occurring in straight and perpendicular lines, which
              appears to be following the line of the waffle pods and/or steel
              below.

The width of these cracks would ordinarily be considered as
              shrinkage cracking, however due to the nature and extent of this
              cracking, it is recommended that the builder arrange for the
              original design engineer to attend site to make comment on the
              severity, and the need or otherwise for rectification. The owner
              should request a copy of the engineer’s comments and/or
              recommendations for their records.

The top of the concrete floor slab throughout this home appears
              to have been rained on shortly after being poured and is now
              dusting, a condition where fine powder comes off the surface of
              the concrete.

The main cause of this condition is rain on the fresh concrete
              surface before it has set which floods the surface and washes out
              or dilutes the cement paste or binder. With insufficient cement
              binder available, the concrete surface dusts.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.11 Finish to Concrete Slabs, states

‘The finish to a concrete slab is defective if it is not
              suitable for the documented applied finishes such as tiles,
              polished concrete, carpet or sheet flooring, including set downs
              where required’ .

The entire top of this slab will require the application of a
              sealer that penetrates the concrete and reacts with the lime in
              it, effectively case hardening the surface; this also bonds the
              thin weak layer on the surface to the base concrete below. This
              work must be carried out prior to the placement of any floor tiles
              and/or coverings and should be done in consultation with the
              original design engineer.

There is visible evidence within the perimeter edge beam that it
              has not been properly vibrated during the pouring process, which
              has left missing areas within the set concrete.
Part 3.2.3.1 Concrete of the BCA requires that

‘Concrete must be placed, compacted and cured in accordance
              with good building practice’

, while the relevant Australian Standard AS 2870 Residential
              Slabs and Footings requires that

‘Concrete in beams shall be mechanically
              vibrated’ .

The builder should have the original design engineer inspect and
              make recommendations on how best to rectify these areas if they
              are deemed to require it, and seek their inspection notice and/or
              approval of this work. The owner should request a copy of the
              engineer’s comments and/or recommendations and ensure that
              any rectification work is carried out under the supervision and
              approval of the building surveyor.

There are steel reinforcement bars visible on the edge of the
              slab, which are exposed to weather and starting to rust. This will
              continue to do so over time, and can possibly lead to the future
              cracking of the slab as well as its possible long-term
              failure.

It is a requirement of section 5.3.2 Reinforcement of AS 2870
              Residential Slabs and Footings, that

‘Reinforcement in rafts and slabs shall be placed with
              minimum concrete cover of the reinforcement shall be 40 mm to
              unprotected ground and 40 mm to external exposure’ .

The builder must properly cut back and treat these areas prior to
              back-filling to ensure the long-term performance of this
              slab.

There has not been a rebate along the edge of the garage door
              provided, allowing water to be directed under the door and into
              the garage, which will damage the building elements.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 1.02 Finish to External Paving states that

‘Concrete paving finish is defective if it is not
              consistent in colour, texture and general appearance’
, while clause 2.11 Finish to Concrete Slabs states that

‘The finish to a concrete slab is defective if it is not
              suitable for the documented applied finishes such as tiles,
              polished concrete, carpet or sheet flooring, including set downs
              where required’ .

This weather rebate must be installed and extended to the full
              width of the garage door, with care taken to keep consistency in
              the finish, as any repair must match the existing floor as closely
              as practical, which may likely require this slab be re-topped (a
              thin concrete screed applied).

The rebate along the edge of the garage slab does not extend to
              the sides of the garage door, which will not allow the door to
              close up tight to the rebate, and will not allow water to be
              diverted away from the door and prevent ingress into the
              garage.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 1.02 Finish to External Paving states that

‘Concrete paving finish is defective if it is not
              consistent in colour, texture and general appearance’
, while clause 2.11 Finish to Concrete Slabs states that

‘The finish to a concrete slab is defective if it is not
              suitable for the documented applied finishes such as tiles,
              polished concrete, carpet or sheet flooring, including set downs
              where required’ .

This weather rebate must be extended to the full width of the
              garage door, with care taken to keep consistency in the finish, as
              any repair must match the existing floor as closely as practical,
              which may likely require this slab be re-topped (a thin concrete
              screed applied).

There has not been a rebate installed into the edge of the slab
              across these walls, resulting in the bricks/cladding sitting at
              the same level as the timber wall plates.

Part 3.2.2.7 Edge Rebates of the Building Code of Australia
              (BCA), requires that

‘an edge rebate for waffle raft slabs with masonry cavity
              or veneer construction must not be less than 20mm; and that the
              edge rebate must be flashed and drained in accordance with Part
              3.3.4’ .

Additionally, Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential

The edges of the floor slab have not been correctly boxed up

              compromise its ability to drain any water and moisture that
              collects in it away from the timber wall framing.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3700 Masonry Structures
              requires that

‘In cavity walls and masonry veneer walls, cavities with a
              width of at least 40mm, which are properly detailed and
              constructed, shall be regarded as being resistant to the passage
              of moisture (with an allowable maximum 15mm deviation from this
              width)’
. Additionally, it requires that

‘Cavities shall be free from mortar droppings or other
              materials that might bridge the cavity and allow transmission of
              moisture’ .

The builder should therefore, after consultation with the slabs
              design engineer, carefully trim back the edges of the slab to
              achieve the required minimum 25mm cavity width, at least down to
              below the damp-proof course/cavity flashing. Consideration should
              be given to not exposing the edge of the steel reinforcement or
              reducing its side cover, not reducing the throat of the edge beam,
              and to any protrusion that may exist on the lower edge of the
              rebate out past the future finished face of the brickwork.

The perimeter of the slab edge beam has various sized concrete
              blowouts and overspills attached to them. These overspills have
              left the vapour barrier in a horizontal orientation, which now
              cannot be wrapped up the side faces of the edge beams in its true
              vertical position as detailed within the NCC’s Building Code
              of Australia (BCA) and Australian Standard AS 2870 Residential
              Slabs and Footings.

It is our advice that the inconsistent widths of these overspills
              result in inconsistent bearing capacities along the length of the
              external walls and will be problematic as they increase the
              effective footing width in random areas. These overspills will
              also remain below the future finished ground level allowing water
              to accumulate on top of them and prevent normal evaporation drying
              of the subsoil moisture.

Overspills prevent expanding soil from sliding past the normally
              vertical edge beam and it follows that these wider areas of edge
              beams can be lifted with less soil expansion forces than the areas
              that do not have them. It must be noted that all footings in the
              BCA and AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings are shown with
              edges of their footings vertical and without overspill.

All of the overspills must be removed from the edges of the edge
              beams, including those areas that have now had soil backfilled
              over them. The builder should have the original design engineer
              make recommendations on how this work should be carried out to
              ensure the slab’s long-term performance.

The owner should ensure that any rectification work is carried
              out under the full supervision and approval of the original design
              engineer and relevant building surveyor.

The National Construction Code (NCC) is produced and maintained
              by the Australian Building Codes Board (ABCB) on behalf of the
              Australian Government and each State and Territory
              Government.

Under the NCC, the Building Code of Australia (BCA) is a uniform
              set of technical provisions for the design and construction of
              buildings and other structures throughout Australia.

There are a number of sections within the BCA that require the
              home to be weatherproof;

Part 2.2 - Damp and weatherproofing of Volume 2 of the BCA states
              the following;

Performance requirement 2.2.2 – Weatherproofing of the BCA
              states that

‘A roof and external wall (including openings around
              windows and doors) must prevent the penetration of water that
              could cause unhealthy or dangerous conditions, or loss of amenity
              for occupants; and undue dampness or deterioration of building
              elements.’

This area is visibly affected by mould, which is putting the
              occupant’s health and amenity at risk. The builder must take
              appropriate steps to not only remove the mould from this home, but
              to then undertake mould testing to ensure that all areas are mould
              free. There are numerous mould testing and removal service
              providers that can be engaged for this issue, and simply
              re-painting the area is not acceptable.

              Holes in Studs and Plates states

‘Studs may be designed as notched or not-notched. For
              common studs, the maximum notch depth for single or upper-storey
              or lower-storey construction shall be 20mm’ .

These over cut wall studs will need to be strengthened with

There has not been jack studs installed within 300mm of the

‘Wall ties for cavity walls and masonry veneer walls shall
              be spaced not greater than 600mm in each direction. Adjacent to
              horizontal and vertical lateral supports and control joints, and
              around openings in the masonry, with the first line of ties
              located within 300mm from the line of lateral support, the control
              joint or the perimeter of opening’ .

Additional jack studs must be installed so the brickwork can be
              tied into the frame within 300mm of the articulation joints in
              accordance with AS 3700.

The external non-loadbearing wall has not been laterally
              restrained properly at the top of the walls.

A proprietary ‘MiTek InternalWall Bracket’ (L
              bracket) is often used in these areas, however the manufacturer
              states in the compliance section of their product information that

‘The InternalWall Bracket conforms with clause 6.2.5.2 of
              AS1684 Residential Timber Framed Construction Parts 2, 3 and 4 for
              fixing
internal non-load bearing walls
to trussed roofs’

. As this is an external wall, these brackets are not appropriate
              for use in this area.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, clause 9.7.6 Shear forces on external
              non-loadbearing walls states that

‘Non-loadbearing external walls, such as gable end walls
              and verandah walls (where trusses are pitched off verandah beams
              or other beams), shall be restrained laterally at their tops at a
              maximum of 3000 mm. Where lateral restraint for these walls is not
              provided by the usual means using binders, intersecting walls,
              strutting, hanging or other roof beams or ceiling joists or
              ceiling battens or similar members, the walls shall be restrained
              laterally in accordance with Table 9.29’ .

These missing structural shear connections must be properly
              installed to the tops of the external braced walls in accordance
              with AS 1684.

There are jack studs that have been installed on their flat above

It is a requirement of Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, clause 6.2.3 Openings, that

‘Jack studs shall be provided in all cases between the
              lintel and the top plate trimmer. Jack studs shall be the same
              size, spacing, and orientation as the common studs’ .

Additionally, the relevant Australian Standard AS 3700 requires
              that

‘Wall ties for cavity and masonry veneer walls shall be
              spaced no greater than 600mm in each direction. Adjacent to
              lateral supports and control joints, and around openings in the
              masonry, with the first line of ties located within 300mm from the
              top of the wall, control joint or perimeter of
              opening’ .

These incorrectly placed jack studs, where the lintels are
              greater than 300mm above the window or door heads, must be
              properly installed before the brickwork is erected so that it can
              be properly tied back to them as required.

The plywood sheet bracing installation is a vital structural

              racking forces, such as wind, are applied to a dwelling. The
              relevant Australian Standard, AS 1684 Residential timber-framed
              construction requires that the edges of the plywood bracing fixed
              at minimum 150mm centres, and the intermediate studs at 300mm
              centres.

Additional fixings must be installed in accordance with AS
              1684.

The plywood sheet bracing installation is a vital structural

              racking forces, such as wind, are applied to a dwelling. The
              relevant Australian Standard, AS 2269 Plywood - Structural, states
              that
‘Holes of up to 100mm x 100mm within

an envelope of 100mm from the vertical and top edges and 200mm of
              the bottom edge of the bracing panel will have no significant
              effect on the bracing capacity. Multiple 100mm x 100mm holes are
              allowable within the envelope but their centres must be no closer
              than 600mm. One hole of up to 400mm x 400mm located between the
              studs and within the envelope defined above, with nogging framing
              the hole and fixing of the plywood to the framing as per the
              requirements for the top and bottom plate is
              acceptable’ .

Additional framing should be installed, with the edges of the
              holes secured with additional fixings.

The National Construction Code (NCC) is produced and maintained
              by the Australian Building Codes Board (ABCB) on behalf of the
              Australian Government and each State and Territory
              Government.

Under the NCC, the Building Code of Australia (BCA) is a uniform
              set of technical provisions for the design and construction of
              buildings and other structures throughout Australia.

There are a number of sections within the BCA that require the
              home to be weatherproof;

Part 2.2 - Damp and weatherproofing of Volume 2 of the BCA states
              the following;

Performance requirement 2.2.2 – Weatherproofing of the BCA
              states that

‘A roof and external wall (including openings around
              windows and doors) must prevent the penetration of water that
              could cause unhealthy or dangerous conditions, or loss of amenity
              for occupants; and undue dampness or deterioration of building
              elements’ .

Additionally, the Victorian Building Authority’s, Guide to
              Standards and Tolerances clause 6.01 Leaks in roofing, flashings
              and accessories states that

‘Roofing, including flashings and accessories, is defective
              if it leaks under normal weather conditions and is due to the
              builder’s workmanship, causes unhealthy or dangerous
              conditions, loss of amenity for occupants, undue dampness or
              deterioration of building elements’ .

The builder must take appropriate steps to investigate and
              address any leaks, prior to replacing/repairing, and re-painting
              the damage caused.

a.
non-combustible; or

a solid timber, laminated timber or reconstituted timber door,

c.
d.

a door, including a hollow core door, protected externally by a

fully framed glazed door, where the framing is made from

              Nail-Plated Timber Roof Trusses, clause 4.3.8 Fixing, provides a
              detail outlining the method for properly bracing cut-off
              trusses;

Diagonal speedbracing must be installed to these cut-off trusses
              in accordance with Australian Standard AS 4440, to ensure the
              performance of the roof bracing system.

The diagonal speedbracing has not been properly fixed to the heel
              of the roof trusses at the girder.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of

              girder;

Diagonal speedbracing must be properly installed to these areas
              in accordance with Australian Standard AS 4440, to ensure the

The diagonal speedbracing that runs across the tops of the

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of
              Nail-Plated Timber Roof Trusses, clause 4.3.8 Fixing, provides a

              plate at the heel;

The fixing of the speedbracing must be rectified in accordance

The roof speedbracing has been spliced or joined
              incorrectly.

The speedbracing must be properly spliced to ensure the
              performance of the roof bracing system.

The roof speedbracing has been spliced or joined over trusses

The manufacturer’s installation guidelines state
              ‘Splice to be located at least 2500mm from heel end fixing,
              measured along brace’.

Additional speedbrace should be installed from the top plate, up
              to at least 2500mm from the heel, where the splice joint may be
              located, to ensure the performance of the roof bracing
              system.

The trusses have not had temporary brace ties installed to the
              top chords at maximum 3000mm centres.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of
              Nail-Plated Timber Roof Trusses, requires that temporary ties are
              to be used on top chords at spacings no greater than 3000mm, and
              on bottom chords at spacings no greater than 4000mm.

These additional top chord ties must be installed as specified in
              the manufacturer’s installation instructions and the
              relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of Nail-Plated
              Timber Roof Trusses, to hold these trusses in the correct
              position.
There is a roof truss that has been cut/modified.

The truss manufacturer warns in the ‘Important Notes’
              section of their installation instructions that

‘Trusses are designed for specific loading, geometry and
              support conditions. Under no circumstances should any component of
              the truss be drilled, cut, removed or modified in any way without
              prior approval from the truss fabricator’ .

Additionally, the relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440
              Installation of Nail-Plated Timber Roof Trusses, clause 3.9 Truss
              Modification, states that

‘Under no circumstances shall a truss be modified by
              cutting, drilling, or by any other method that may interfere with
              its structural integrity, without being approved. If any truss has
              been cut, drilled, damaged, or manufactured in such a way as to
              impair performance, notification should be given to the truss
              engineer in order to provide adequate rectification to the
              truss’ .

The builder should consult the roof truss manufacturer to provide
              documentation and/or a design for the rectification, or otherwise
              to confirm that the current installation is acceptable. The
              builder should provide a copy of the documentation from the
              manufacturer to the owner for their records.

Roof trusses have been incorrectly blocked/wedged down onto the
              top plates of non-loadbearing walls, making them loadbearing, and
              not allowing the trusses to deflect as they were designed
              to.
T

he relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential Timber-Framed
              Construction, states in section 6.2.5.2 Internal Walls –
              Trussed Roofs, that

‘Non-Loadbearing walls shall be kept a minimum of 10mm
              below the underside of the bottom chord, or ceiling battens when
              used’ .

Also, Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated
              Timber Roof Trusses, states in section 2.2.2 Non-Loadbearing
              Walls, states that

‘Non-loadbearing walls, as designated, shall not carry any
              truss loading and shall not be packed to touch the underside of
              trusses (see Figure 2.1)’ .

Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated Timber
              Roof Trusses, also state in Appendix B2 Camber, that

‘Trusses are built with camber to allow for the initial
              deflection at the take up of load and some creep (i.e. long-term
              deflection) as the timber settles. Thus, packing to the underside
              of a truss over a non-loadbearing wall may stop these deflections
              and in turn support the truss in an incorrect
              position’ .

These areas will need to be reconstructed to allow the trusses to
              deflect as designed, by using an alternate method to straighten
              the ceiling line.

The shear blocks have been incorrectly constructed, blocking the
              trusses down onto the top plate of the non-loadbearing walls,
              making them loadbearing, and not allowing the trusses to deflect
              as they were designed to.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, states in section 6.2.5.2 Internal
              Walls – Trussed Roofs, that

‘Non-Loadbearing walls shall be kept a minimum of 10mm

              used’ .

Also, Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated
              Timber Roof Trusses, states in section 2.2.2 Non-Loadbearing
              Walls, that

‘Non-loadbearing walls, as designated, shall not carry any
              truss loading and shall not be packed to touch the underside of
              trusses (see Figure 2.1)’ .

Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated Timber
              Roof Trusses, also state in Appendix B2 Camber, that

‘Trusses are built with camber to allow for the initial
              deflection at the take up of load and some creep (i.e. long-term
              deflection) as the timber settles. Thus, packing to the underside
              of a truss over a non-load-bearing wall may stop these deflections
              and in turn support the truss in an incorrect
              position’ .

These shear blocks will need to be reconstructed to allow the

There are trusses where the heel overhangs the support by more

These trusses must be properly supported in accordance with the

There are roof trusses that have been installed out of plumb,
              outside the maximum allowable tolerances documented in the
              standards.

The truss manufacturer’s erection tolerances, and the
              relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of Nail-Plated
              Timber Roof Trusses, states that

‘Tolerance is critical for both a good roof line and
              effective bracing. Trusses to be erected so that no part of the
              truss is out of plumb with a tolerance exceeding the lesser of
              height/50 and 50 mm’ ;

These trusses must be properly plumbed back to within the
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s allowable erection
              tolerances otherwise they may possibly fail. Alternatively, the
              builder should provide the owner with documentation from the
              manufacturer to confirm that the current installation is
              acceptable.

There are roof trusses that have been installed with a large bow,

The truss manufacturer’s erection tolerances, and the

              Timber Roof Trusses, states that

‘Tolerance is critical for both a good roof line and
              effective bracing. Trusses to be erected with minimal bow, in the
              truss and in any chord, with a tolerance not exceeding the lesser
              of L/200 and 50mm, where L is as defined as shown in
              diagrams’ ;

These trusses must be properly straightened back to within the
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s allowable erection
              tolerances otherwise they may possibly fail. Alternatively, the

There have not been anti-skid blocks installed under the valley

, see below;

, and

, see below;

The carpet is starting to fray, which will continue to worsen

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and

that

‘Joins in carpet and vinyl are defective if they
              peak, fray or misalign and are visible from a normal viewing
              position within 12 months from handover.’ .
The carpet in this area must be rectified or replaced.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and

that

‘Joins in carpet and vinyl are defective if they
              peak, fray or misalign and are visible from a normal viewing
              position within 12 months from handover.’

The carpet join in this area must be rectified so it is no longer

There are decking boards that are splitting due the installed

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 14.09 Splitting of timber decking states that

‘Splits in timber decking that extend to the end or side
              edge of the timber is defective if they are due to the fixing

The effected decking boards will need to be replaced in

The floor has been constructed visibly out of level.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 14.08 Levelness of Timber Floors, states

‘New floors are defective if within the first 24 months of
              handover they differ in level by more than 10mm in any room or
              area, or more than 4mm in any 2m length’ .

The floor in this area will need to be properly rectified so that
              it complies with this tolerance.
The flooring is springy/bouncy when walked upon.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 14.07 Springy floors states that

‘Floors that bounce in a way that can be detected by a
              person walking normally in a trafficable area are defective if the
              substructure has not been constructed in accordance with the
              Building Code of Australia and AS 1684’ .
This floor must be rectified in accordance with above.
The flooring squeaks when walked upon.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 14.06 Squeaking floors states that

‘Floors that consistently squeak by a person walking
              normally in a trafficable area within the first 24 months from
              handover are defective’ .

This floor must be rectified in accordance with the above
              requirements.

The finished floor level of this home is stepped/on different

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 2.07 Finished floor levels states that

‘Finished floor levels (FFL) or reduced levels (RL) are
              defective where floors are documented to be on the same plane but
              are constructed on different planes, or the building work is an
              extension or addition and new floor levels do not match the
              existing building floor levels’ .

The finished floor height of this area will need to be
              re-constructed in accordance with above.

The fixings installed into the sheet flooring have been driven
              too deep through the sheets.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1860.2 Particleboard Flooring
              – Installation in section 10.3 Nails states that

‘Nailing machines shall be adjusted so that the heads of
              the nails penetrate the surface by not more than 1mm. The use of a
              flush drive attachment, a chisel drive nail machine or similar is
              required’ .

These sheets will need to have additional fixings installed to
              the joists at no greater than 150mm centres on their ends, and
              300mm centres on intermediate joists as required by AS 1860. Care
              must be taken to ensure that these fixings are driven no further
              than 1mm deep.

The flooring throughout this home has only been nailed, not
              screwed to the floor joists. I note that the builder may have
              intended to screw these flooring sheets at a later stage, which is
              not un-common. If particleboard flooring is not properly glued and
              screwed to the floor joists, the flooring becomes susceptible to
              squeaking over time, often starting to squeak even before the home
              is completed.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 1860.2 Particleboard
              Flooring - Installation, clause 10.4 Screws states that

‘If particleboard flooring is fixed to I-beam and truss
              joists, screws (not nails) should be used’ .

These sheets will need to have screws properly installed to the
              joists at no greater than 150mm centres on their ends, and 300mm
              centres on intermediate joists as required by AS 1860.2 and AS
              1684.

              General Requirements states that

‘Square edge joints shall be butted centrally over joists
              or trimmers’ .

The builder will need to provide solid blocking/trimmers to

‘sheets shall be securely glued and nailed to the top edge

These sheets need to be properly fixed to the joists at no

The edges of the particleboard flooring around the set downs have

There are areas in the flooring where there is a single span

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential

              states that

‘Sheets shall span not less than two floor joist

Although this sheet should not be installed in this manner at

‘Where possible, each panel shall be supported by not less

              by AS 1860.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3958.1 Ceramic Tiles - Guide
              to the Installation of Ceramic Tiles, clause 5.4.5 Movement
              Joints, states

‘Intermediate movement joints should be inserted at

              floors where any dimension exceeds 9m or 6m if subject to
              sunlight’
and that

‘Perimeter joints should be inserted where the tiling abuts
              restraining surfaces such as perimeter walls or
              columns’ .

Additionally, the Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to
              Standards and Tolerances, clause 11.10 Movement joints states that

‘Tiled floors are defective if intermediate movement joints
              are not inserted at evenly spaced positions at approximately 4.5m
              centres or at locations where stress might reasonably be expected
              in internal floors where any dimension exceeds 9m or 6m if
              subjected to sunlight, or external floors where any dimension
              exceeds 4.5m’ .

The present tiling must be rectified in accordance with the above
              requirements to accommodate these movement joints to avoid future
              cracking.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 13.06 Decks and balcony freeboard outside
              windows and doors states that

‘Waterproof decks and balconies are defective if they do
              not have a drainage system sufficient to withstand wind-driven
              water surging from the deck or balcony that complies with the
              Building Code of Australia and AS 4654.2. See Diagram
              13.06;’ .

Additionally, section 2.8.1.3 of AS 4654.2 - Membrane Termination
              Flashing, states that

‘a membrane shall be finished with an
              over-flashing’
, and

‘The termination of an over-flashing shall comply with the
              following;
i.

The over-flashing shall be attached into the waterproof wall via
              a reglet of minimum 15mm and shall be fixed in place and sealed
              with sealant.
ii.

The lap from the top edge of the sealed reglet to the bottom of
              the fully bonded membrane shall be a minimum of 75mm.
iii.

There shall be a minimum 10mm gap between the bottom of the
              flashing and the finished level’ .

              windows’.

There have not been clearance gaps provided to the side of the
              door opening at the articulation joint nominated by the engineer,
              which will stop their ability to move when it experiences the
              expected brick growth and foundation movement.

Articulation joints are the vertical gaps constructed into clay
              brickwork to absorb the expected structural movement of the
              building’s foundation material, and just as importantly to
              act as control joints to absorb the expected growth in the clay
              bricks from long-term thermal expansion. Brick manufacturers allow
              for an estimated 15 year coefficient of expansion of between 0.3
              to 0.9mm per metre of brickwork, which would equate to between 5
              and 15mm of possible expansion over the longer external walls of
              this home.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3700 Masonry Structures
              requires in section 12.4.3 Movement Control Joints, that

‘Expansion joints (closing control joints) and articulation
              joints shall be clean and free from any hard or incompressible
              material for the full width and depth of the joint before
              joint-filling material (if any) is inserted’ .

Additionally, Part 3.3.1.8 Vertical Articulation Joints, of the
              NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires that

‘Vertical articulation joints between masonry elements must
              have a width not less than 10mm’

, and the Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards
              and Tolerances clause 3.03 Movement; control joints in masonry
              walls, states that

‘Control joints are defective if they do not extend through
              the full thickness of masonry skin’ .

This articulation joint must be properly installed before the
              surrounding works proceed any further. Alternatively, the builder
              should provide evidence from the engineer to the owners that this
              joint can be omitted.

Articulation joints are the vertical gaps constructed into clay
              brickwork to absorb the expected structural movement of the
              building’s foundation material, and just as importantly to
              act as control joints to absorb the expected growth in the clay
              bricks from long-term thermal expansion. Brick manufacturers allow
              for an estimated 15 year coefficient of expansion of between 0.3
              to 0.9mm per metre of brickwork, which would equate to between 5
              and 15mm of possible expansion over the longer external walls of
              this home.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3700 Masonry Structures
              requires in section 12.4.3 Movement Control Joints, that

‘Expansion joints (closing control joints) and articulation
              joints shall be clean and free from any hard or incompressible
              material for the full width and depth of the joint before
              joint-filling material (if any) is inserted’ .

Additionally, Part 3.3.1.8 Vertical Articulation Joints, of the
              NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires that

‘Vertical articulation joints between masonry elements must
              have a width not less than 10mm’

, and the Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards
              and Tolerances clause 3.03 Movement; control joints in masonry
              walls, states that

‘Control joints are defective if they do not extend through
              the full thickness of masonry skin’ .

This articulation joint must be properly installed before the
              surrounding works proceed any further. Alternatively, the builder
              should provide evidence from the engineer to the owners that this
              joint can be omitted.

The articulation joint nominated by the engineer in this area has
              not been installed through both skins of brickwork (inside and
              outside), which will be restricting articulation movement of the
              joint when it experiences the expected brick growth and foundation
              movement.

Th

e relevant Australian Standard, AS 3700 Masonry Structures,
              requires in section 3.4 Ties & Accessories that

‘The type and duty rating of wall ties shall be specified.
              Where they are designed to connect structural elements, the design
              strength and stiffness of accessories shall also be
              specified’
, and that

‘The mean tie strength (Ft) of Type A veneer wall ties
              shall be not less than the values given in Table 3.5. The design
              strength of Type A cavity wall ties shall be not less than the
              values given in Table 3.6’ .

As these ties do not have the type and duty rating specified, and
              clearly do not meet the requirements of the Australian Standards,
              these sections of brickwork will either need to be demolished and
              reconstructed using appropriate brick ties, or otherwise the
              builder will need to have these ties tested in a laboratory to
              confirm they comply with the provisions of Australian Standard AS
              2699.1 Wall ties for masonry construction, and Australian Standard
              AS 3700 (shown above).

              support the edge of the wall on the side of the articulation joint
              (AJ).

Part 3.3.5.10 Wall ties of the NCC’s Building Code of
              Australia (BCA) requires that

‘Veneer wall ties must be spaced and fixed in accordance
              with Table 3.3.5.3b’ .

Additionally, Australian Standard, AS 3700 - Masonry Structures
              requires in section 4.10 Wall Ties that

‘Wall ties for cavity and masonry veneer walls shall be
              spaced no greater than 600mm in each direction. Adjacent to
              lateral supports and control joints, and around openings in the
              masonry, with the first line of ties located within 300mm from the
              top of the wall, control joint or perimeter of
              opening’ .

As there are no brick ties in this area, and Australian Standard
              AS 3700 states that

‘Wall ties and accessories embedded in mortar joints shall
              be built in as the construction proceeds’

, this section of brickwork will need to be demolished and

              accordance with the requirements of the Building Code of Australia
              (BCA) and relevant standards.

The wall ties are covered in mortar build-up, which will allow

Part 3.3.5.6 Cavities of the NCC’s Building Code of
              Australia (BCA) requires that

‘The clear width of a cavity between the masonry veneer and
              the exterior face of the supporting frame must be not less than
              25mm wide and where the masonry veneer is constructed on a
              slab-on-ground, the cavity must be drained to the
              outside’

. Additionally, Australian Standard AS 3700 Masonry Structures,
              requires in section 4.7 Prevention of Moisture Penetration, that

‘The cavities shall be free of obstruction that would allow
              moisture across the cavity, clean and continuous, and not bridged
              other than by ties or accessories, flashings, doors, windows, head
              jambs and sills’
, and also that

‘The cavities shall be free of obstruction that would allow
              moisture across the cavity, clean and continuous, and not bridged
              other than by ties or accessories, flashings, doors, windows, head
              jambs and sills’ .

All of the excess mortar must be properly and carefully removed
              to protect against moisture transfer.

and that

              rectification will need to be decided upon i.e. the grinding out
              and repointing of every bed and perpend joint; or if the owners
              are prepared to accept it, the rendering of the walls (we
              recommend a 4-coat system) keeping in mind the ongoing associated
              maintenance costs of render.

There are sections of brickwork that are displaying rust like
              deposits on the faces of the mortar joints due to acid
              staining.

There are a number of causes of this problem, the most common
              being when too much acid and not enough water is used in the
              initial clean, which causes a reaction between the acid and the
              brick’s clay base to be absorbed into the mortar
              joints.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 3.11, Cleaning, Mortar Smears & Stains
              states that

‘Stains, mortar smears and damage caused by cleaning are
              defects if they are visible from a normal viewing
              positioning’.

These areas should be properly re-cleaned with a product approved
              by the brick manufacturer to remove this staining, with care to
              ensure that the brickwork and mortar joints are not damaged.

              brick’s clay base to be absorbed into the mortar
              joints.

There are sections of brickwork that are displaying greenish
              mould-like film on the face of the bricks.

There are a number of causes of this problem, the most common
              being too strong a concentration of hydrochloric acid during the
              initial cleaning process. Light coloured bricks contain vanadium
              salts which will react between the acid and the bricks if too
              strong an acid mix is used.

              states that

These areas should be properly re-cleaned with a product approved

The timber wall framing is in direct contact with the brickwork,
              which will allow moisture from the brickwork to be transferred
              into the unprotected wall framing members, causing them to
              rot.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 3700 Masonry Structures, in
              section 4.7 Prevention of Moisture Penetration, states that

‘In cavity walls and masonry veneer walls, cavities with a
              width of at least 40 mm, which are properly detailed and
              constructed, shall be regarded as being resistant to the passage
              of moisture from the exposed face through to the inner, unexposed
              face of the wall. Where insulating material is placed in a cavity,
              appropriate measures shall be taken to ensure that the moisture
              resistance of the wall is maintained’
, and also that

‘The cavities shall be free of obstruction that would allow
              moisture across the cavity, clean and continuous, and not bridged
              other than by ties or accessories, flashings, doors, windows, head
              jambs and sills’ .

These walls will need to be reconstructed to ensure that moisture
              from the brickwork cannot be transferred into the unprotected wall
              frames.

The brickwork has been installed hard up to the underside of the
              beams, not allowing the frame to move/shrink as it settles.

Part 3.3.1.10 Shrinkage Allowance for Timber Framing of the
              NCC’s Building Code of Australia requires that

‘In masonry veneer walls a gap must be left between the
              timber frame and the top of the masonry wall, including window
              sills etc, to allow for settlement of the timber framing caused by
              timber shrinkage. These clearances must be not less than 5mm at
              sills of lower and single storey windows; and 8mm at roof
              overhangs of single storey buildings’ .

Additionally, Australian Standard AS 4773 - Masonry for Small
              Buildings requires in clause 9.5 Allowance for timber shrinkage,
              that

‘Consideration shall be given to timber
              shrinkage’ .

The brickwork below these beams will need to be lowered to
              achieve the required clearance in accordance with above.

It is a requirement of Part 3.2.2.6 Vapour Barriers of the

‘The vapour barrier must be placed beneath the slab so that
              the bottom surface of the slab is entirely underlaid and extends

              Figure 3.2.2.3’
, shown below;

Additionally, the relevant Australian Standard AS 2870 Slab &
              Footing Construction, clause 5.3.3 Vapour Barriers and
              Damp-proofing Membranes states that

‘Vapour barriers shall be installed so that the bottom
              surface of the slab and beams, including internal beams, is
              entirely underlaid. The membrane shall extend under the edge beam
              to ground level’ .

The shrinkage cuts installed into the concrete paving are not
              deep enough, which will likely contribute to cracking. It should
              be noted that there are already small" Category 1 and 2
              cracks appearing.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3727 Guide to Residential
              Pavement requires these cuts to be between 1/4 to 1/3 the depth of
              the concrete.

Given that this driveway paving should be a minimum of 100mm
              thick these cuts need to be between 25 and 33mm deep.

As these cracks are at this stage only classified as Category 1

              Authority’s Guide to Standards and Tolerances, they should
              be monitored for a period of 12 months after settlement and
              rectified if they worsen to a category 3 or higher.

It is a requirement of Part 3.2.2.6 Vapour Barriers of the BCA
              that

‘The vapour barrier must be placed beneath the slab so that

The angle bracing has only been fixed to the studs and plates
              with one nail (or none).

It is a requirement of Australian Standard, AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, that there be a minimum of 2/30 x
              2.8mm nails to each stud and plate.

There must be additional nails installed in accordance with AS
              1684.

The bulkheads have been fixed directly to the trusses, and also
              to the adjoining walls. This makes the non-loadbearing walls
              load-bearing, and not does not allow the trusses to deflect as
              they were designed to.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, states in section 6.2.5.2 Internal
              Walls – Trussed Roofs, that

‘Non-Loadbearing walls shall be kept a minimum of 10mm
              below the underside of the bottom chord, or ceiling battens when
              used’.

Also, Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated
              Timber Roof Trusses, states in section 2.2.2 Non-Loadbearing
              Walls, states that

‘Non-loadbearing walls, as designated, shall not carry any
              truss loading and shall not be packed to touch the underside of
              trusses (see Figure 2.1)’ .

Australian Standard AS 4440 Installation of Nail-plated Timber
              Roof Trusses, also state in Appendix B2 Camber, that

‘Trusses are built with camber to allow for the initial
              deflection at the take up of load and some creep (i.e. long-term
              deflection) as the timber settles. Thus, packing to the underside
              of a truss over a non-loadbearing wall may stop these deflections
              and in turn support the truss in an incorrect
              position’ .

These areas will need to be reconstructed to allow the trusses to
              deflect as designed, by using an alternate method to support the
              bulkhead, such as a lintel beam selected from AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction. There is information in clause 6.3.6.5
              Lintels in Non-Loadbearing Internal Walls to assist in selection
              of a lintel beam for this bulkhead opening, stating that

‘Where wall openings wider than 1800mm occur in
              non-loadbearing walls, a lintel shall be provided and the size of
              the lintel shall be determined from Span Table 23’ .

The builder must establish the correct sized lintel for this
              bulkhead opening and install it into the wall in compliance with
              the requirements of AS 4440 and AS 1684.

              new sewer pipework.

There have not been sufficient clearances provided around the
              stove/cooktop.

There are various design issues that need to be considered for
              stove/cooktop hobs;

1. The minimum space allowed between the cooktop elements or gas
              burners and combustible materials directly overhead is
              600mm.

2. There must be at least 50 mm clearance from the back edge of
              the cooktop to a non-combustible wall surface or splashback.

3. There must be at least 300 mm horizontal clearance from the
              outside edge of an electric element or gas burner to a combustible
              surface on the side of a cooktop. Combustible surfaces include
              adjoining cabinets faced with melamine or plastic laminate

This area will need to be re-constructed to ensure that adequate
              clearances are provided to all sides of the stove/cooktop hob to
              prevent fire hazards.

There has not been adequate clearance provided between the
              switch/power outlet to the sink/basin.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3000 Wiring Rules states in
              section 6.2.2.2 that there must be 150mm clearance to the side of
              the water container, and 400mm above the water container.

The location of this switch/power outlet will need to be
              relocated to ensure proper clearance in accordance with Australian
              Standard AS 3000.

              cabling’

These telecommunication (data) cables and the electrical wiring

The National Construction Code (NCC) is produced and maintained
              by the Australian Building Codes Board (ABCB) on behalf of the
              Australian Government and each State and Territory
              Government.

Under the NCC, the Building Code of Australia (BCA) is a uniform
              set of technical provisions for the design and construction of
              buildings and other structures throughout Australia.

There are a number of sections within the BCA that mention the
              need to

‘safeguard the occupants from illness or injury and protect
              the building from damage’ .

The presence of pests in this area is putting the
              occupant’s health and amenity at risk. Therefore, the
              builder must take appropriate steps to not only to safely remove
              the pests from this home, but to then undertake proper cleaning
              and sanitising of the area to ensure that there are no risks of
              future issue. The builder should also take steps to address the
              access of the pests in the area to ensure that they cannot
              return.

, and

The floor slab has been boxed and poured short along the wall,
              which has left the wall overhanging the edge of the floor slab,
              and the builder has attempted to rectify this issue by installing
              a grout-based product that likely has little or no vertical
              adhesion to the slab, resulting in this grout repair contributing
              almost nothing to resolving this issue.

Grout is a very strong product for transferring load down onto a
              slab underneath, but has almost no vertical adhesion properties.
              If the builder is to rely on this grout repair as an adequate
              solution to the overhang, they should provide evidence to the
              owner that the product used can support the weight of the wall
              with the friction alone on the edge of the slab.

Otherwise, this will need to be re-constructed on site to reflect
              the designed requirements of the approved engineering drawings, or
              be re-designed with a supporting metal angle (or similar) and
              certified by the original design engineer. The building surveyor
