The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 8.02 Weather-tightness of windows, doors, and
              window and door frames states that

‘Window frame and door frame installations are defective
              if, due to the builder’s workmanship, they leak or cause
              unhealthy or dangerous conditions, loss of amenity for occupants,
              undue dampness or deterioration of building elements’ .

Additionally, Australian Standard 2047 - Windows and external
              glazed doors states in section 7.2.2 Flashing that

'Flashing shall be incorporated into the building envelope
              where it is necessary—

(a) to restrict water from entering into the interior of a
              building from the exterior;

(b) to restrict water passing across a cavity to the inner leaf;
              or
(c) to shed water through cladding to the outer face.

Window flashings must be installed in accordance with the above
              requirement to avoid water leaks, or pest ingress that may cause
              unhealthy conditions or damage the building elements.

The particleboard flooring appears to have been exposed to
              weather for an extended period of time, which may have caused
              damage to the flooring sheets.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1860.2 Particleboard Flooring
              – Installation in section 11 Protection of Installed
              Particleboard Flooring states that

‘As soon as practicable after fixing, particleboard
              flooring shall be protected from the weather, preferably by the
              installation of roof covering and external wall cladding. The
              maximum exposure time shall be 3 months’ .
It also states that

'Particleboard flooring would be expected to perform
              satisfactorily, in most cases, after more than 3 months weather
              exposure. However, if the 3 months exposure is exceeded, the
              particleboard-flooring manufacturer should be called upon to
              provide a written opinion as to whether the floor is satisfactory.
              If the manufacturer considers the floor to be unsatisfactory,
              appropriate remedial action should be specified' .

The builder must request that the manufacturer attend site to
              provide comment on these sheets, as required by AS 1860. The owner
              should request copies of the formal correspondence from the
              flooring manufacturer, or alternatively, these sheets should all
              be replaced.

There are holes and divots in the top of the sheet flooring where
              floor coverings are to be installed.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances states that the substrate must be suitable for the
              documented applied finishes such as tiles, carpet or sheet
              flooring, including set downs where required.

These areas must be properly filled or replaced to avoid future
              low spots in the floor coverings.
The flooring installation has not been fully completed.

This flooring must be properly completed (and should be
              inspected) prior to works in this area continuing any

The flooring frame has been constructed out of level, with water
              visibly pooling in areas, which is likely to be damaging the
              particleboard flooring sheets.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1860.2 Particleboard Flooring
              – Installation in section 11 Protection of Installed
              Particleboard Flooring states that

‘Any ponded water should be removed as soon as practicable.
              This can be achieved by drilling holes of 3 mm maximum diameter,
              at not less than 1 m spacing, through the floor where ponding
              occurs’ .

Additionally, with reference to the out of level flooring, the
              Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 14.08 Levelness of Timber Floors, states

‘New floors are defective if within the first 24 months of
              handover they differ in level by more than 10mm in any room or
              area, or more than 4mm in any 2m length’ .

The pooling water must be immediately removed, and the floor in
              this area will need to be properly rectified so that it complies
              with this tolerance.

The wall insulation batts have not yet been properly fitted in
              all external wall areas between the framing members, to properly
              insulate this home.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3999 Thermal Insulation of
              Dwellings - Bulk Insulation - Installation Requirements, states in
              section 5.4.3.1 that

‘Bulk insulation when installed between wall studs shall be
              in contact with and fit tightly between studs, top and bottom
              plates and noggings. See Figure 5.4.3.1.1’.

The missing wall insulation batts must be fully installed and
              properly restrained into position prior to plaster installation.

We strongly recommend a reinspection, as in our experience,
              builders rarely install insulation correctly, which will effect
              the thermal performance of the home and cost the occupants
              additional money to keep the home heated and cooled each year.

The ceiling insulation batts have not been properly restrained
              during installation, resulting in areas where these batts have
              fallen out (or are falling out), which will be
              difficult/impossible to check later, and may not be properly
              installed before plaster.

It is a requirement of Section 3.12.1.1 Building Fabric Thermal
              Insulation of the NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA)
              that

‘insulation must be installed so that it abuts or overlaps
              adjoining insulation other than at supporting members such as
              columns, studs, noggings, joists, furring channels and the like
              where the insulation must butt against the member; and forms a
              continuous barrier with ceilings, walls, bulkheads, floors or the
              like that inherently contribute to the thermal
              barrier’ .

Additionally, Sustainability Victoria’s Energy Smart
              Housing Manual warns that

‘if ends and edges of batts are not snugly fitted then up
              to 5% of the ceiling area will not be properly covered, which
              would lose up to 50% of the potential insulation
              benefit’

. The relevant Australian Standard AS 3900 Bulk Thermal
              Insulation also requires that the entire ceiling area be fully
              insulated.

This insulation needs to be properly installed and restrained in
              all areas to achieve the required R-value across the entire roof
              area.

There is a thin section of wall where the insulation batts have
              not been properly fitted between the framing members.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 3999 Thermal Insulation of
              Dwellings - Bulk Insulation - Installation Requirements, states in
              section 5.4.3.1 that

‘Bulk insulation when installed between wall studs shall be
              in contact with and fit tightly between studs, top and bottom
              plates and noggings. See Figure 5.4.3.1.1’ .

The missing batts must be fully installed and properly restrained
              into position prior to plaster installation.

The section of wall in this area is open to the substrate, where
              fibre insulation batts have been installed. These fibres can
              easily move through the cavity and into the air inside the home,
              creating a potential health risk for the occupants.

There is a great amount of information available to consumers and
              home-owners on the health risks of airborne insulation fibres.
              Instead, we recommend that the builder take steps to seal the area
              between the insulated cavity, and the open section to the
              habitable areas to prevent the issue completely.

Alternatively, the builder should provide further information for
              the owner on the exact products used and the risks associated for
              their records.

It appears that the builder has installed 'thermal'
              insulation in the areas where 'acoustic' (sound)
              insulation should be installed.

Although it is difficult to be 100% certain about which
              insulation has been installed in these areas, we suspect that the
              incorrect insulation type has been used, as the acoustic batts are
              often different in colour and/or texture.

Instead of asserting that this is the case, we instead ask that
              the builder investigate further to provide evidence to the owner
              that these insulation batts have the same acoustic efficiency
              rating as the contractual documentation requires. Should the
              insulation be the incorrect type, it should be replaced prior to
              plasterboard installation, and the owner given an opportunity to
              inspect them.

There is an oversized/inconsistent gap in this area where a

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 10.01 Gaps associated with internal fixing
              states that

‘Unless documented otherwise, gaps between mouldings or
              between mouldings and other fixtures, at mitre or butt joints, or
              at junctions with a wall or other surfaces, are defective if they
              exist at handover, or exceed 1 mm in width within the first 12
              months of completion and are visible from a normal viewing
              position’ .

Additionally, the builder warrants that the work will be carried
              out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’

, which is not the case in this area, and should be rectified
              prior to handover.

The 90x35mm pine ceiling joists installed in this area exceed the
              maximum span of 1700mm (single span), or 2200mm (continuous span).

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction, in Table 21 - Ceiling Joists for
              90x35mm MGP10 Pine, only allows for a span of 1700mm (single
              span), or 2200mm (continuous span). See below;

As these maximum spans have been exceeded, which could result in
              the ceiling sagging (or failure), the builder should either
              upgrade the timber size/strength grade, or provide additional
              supports to reduce the spans to within these requirements.

The ceiling joists in this area are spaced at greater than 600mm
              centres, which will not properly support the ceiling plasterboard
              sheets.

The relevant Australian Standards AS 1684 and AS 2589.1, and the
              plaster manufacturer all require that the ceiling framing members
              be spaced at maximum 600mm centres to properly support the ceiling
              plasterboard, to prevent sagging or failure.

Additional joists, battens, or trimmers will need to be installed
              so that the plasterboard sheets can be securely fixed to the
              framing at their required centres.

The floor slab has been boxed and poured short along the wall,
              which has left the steel column that supports the loads above
              overhanging the edge of the floor slab, which must be properly
              supported to prevent failure.

The engineering documents on all projects are very clear that
              steel columns must have full support onto the slab to ensure that
              loads are properly transferred down. Additionally, the Victorian
              Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and Tolerances
              clause 4.08 Bottom Plates that Overhang Concrete Slabs states that

‘Bottom plates that are 90 mm wide or greater and overhang
              concrete slabs by more than 10 mm are defective’ .

The original design engineer should be consulted to confirm a
              rectification design, and this must be completed prior to any
              further loading on the frame. The owner should request copies of
              the revised engineering design detail for their records.

There is a gap between the steel column and concrete slab,
              resulting in the base plate not being fully supported, which will
              need to be filled using a non-shrink structural grout
              product.

There are often details or notes provided for this specific
              detail in the engineering documents, which should be followed.
              Alternatively, the builder should confirm with the engineer which
              non-shrink structural grout product (or similar) would be suitable
              for this rectification, prior to the works being carried
              out.

The loadbearing wall in this area does not have a lintel beam
              installed, which will result in the frame sagging and possible
              failure.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1684 Residential
              Timber-Framed Construction states in section 6.2.3 Openings, that

'Openings shall be framed with jamb studs and
              lintels' .

The builder should install a correctly sized lintel beam into
              this opening in accordance with the engineering and AS1684, prior
              to works in this area proceeding any further.
There is a roof truss that has not been installed.

The relevant Australian Standard, AS 4440 Installation of
              Nail-Plated Timber Roof Trusses, requires that roof truss framing
              must be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's
              installation details, which will require that the missing trusses
              be immediately installed.

There is a floor joist that has not been installed into the floor

As this is an engineered floor frame system, the omission of this

              install the floor frame in accordance with the floor frame
              engineering design, which will require this joist be installed
              prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The floor joists in this area are spaced too far apart for the

The relevant Australian Standard AS 1860.2 Particleboard Flooring
              – Installation in section 8 Floor Frame Installation states
              that

‘The centre-to-centre joist spacing over which flooring
              panels are to be laid shall not exceed the maximum permissible
              span marked on the panels, e.g., 450 mm for 19 mm, and 600 mm for
              22 mm thick panel, respectively’ .

Additionally, the floor frame engineering design will likely have
              allowed for the floor joist spacings in accordance with AS1860.2
              & AS1684.

These sheets will need to have additional joists or trimmers
              installed at no greater than the maximum centres in accordance
              with the above.

This section of the dwelling has a gap that not been properly
              sealed to the external wall, floor or roof cavities, which will
              allow air movement and reduce the energy efficiency of this
              home.

Part 3.12.3 Building Sealing of the NCC’s Building Code of
              Australia (BCA) requires in section 3.12.3.5 that

'Ceilings, walls, floors and any opening such as a window
              frame, door frame, roof light frame or the like must be
              constructed to minimise air leakage when forming part of the
              external fabric of a conditioned space, or a habitable
              room' .

This section of the BCA also includes a paragraph on how it
              should be constructed to avoid air leakage in section 3.12.3.5

'Construction must be enclosed by internal lining systems
              that are close fitting at ceiling, wall and floor junctions; or
              sealed at junctions and penetrations with close-fitting
              architrave, skirting or cornice; or expanding foam, rubber
              compressive strip, caulking or the like' .

These building air gaps must be sealed in all areas in accordance
              with the building code requirements above.

The exhaust fans have not been fitted with a sealing device such
              as a self-closing damper to prevent air leakage from the
              building.

Part 3.12.3 Building Sealing of the NCC’s Building Code of
              Australia (BCA) requires in section 3.12.3.4 Exhaust Fans that

'An exhaust fan must be fitted with a sealing device such as
              a self-closing damper, filter or the like when serving a
              conditioned space, or a habitable room' .

These exhaust fan air gaps must be sealed in all areas in
              accordance with the building code requirements above. This may
              require fitting a self-closing damper, or possibly replacing the
              exhaust fans with a type that meets the building code
              requirements.

The floor screed in this wet area has been completed, however

Part 3.8.1.2 of the NCC's Building Code of Australia (BCA) -
              Wet Areas, states that;

Table 3.8.1.1 in the NCC/BCA shows that these areas must be
              waterproofed.

The builder must install waterproofing to these area as required
              by the NCC’s Building Code of Australia and Australian
              Standard AS 3740.

There is a visible hole in the waterproofing membrane in the
              floor area, which could result in a long-term water leak that can
              cause damage to the structure and surrounding areas.

The NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires in
              section 3.8.1.2 Wet Areas that where timber, particleboard or ply
              flooring is used, the floor of the entire wet area room be
              waterproofed. The relevant Australian Standard AS 1860.2
              Particleboard Flooring – Installation in Appendix D, Wet
              Area Floor states that

‘The particleboard-flooring surface should be
              waterproofed’ .

Additionally, the flooring manufacturer states in the Wet Area
              Installation section of their technical data manual that

‘Particleboard flooring provides an economical flooring
              option for the application of impervious waterproofing systems in
              wet areas such as bathrooms, laundries and toilets. The
              waterproofing of floors and floor/wall joints in these areas is
              essential to prevent water damage to the substructure and
              adjoining rooms or spaces’ .

These areas must be fully waterproofed to protect the flooring
              and other building elements from damage in accordance with the
              BCA, Australian Standards and manufacturer’s
              requirements.

The waterproofing membrane in this area is starting to delaminate
              from the substrate, indicating that either the substrate has not
              been properly cleaned and primed, or the waterproofing membrane
              has not been properly installed.

Part 3.8.1.2 of the NCC's Building Code of Australia (BCA) -
              Wet Areas, states that;

Additionally, the builder warrants that the work will be carried
              out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’
, which is not the case in this area.

These areas must be rectified to be fully waterproofed to protect
              the building elements from damage in accordance with the BCA,
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s requirements.

The waterproofing membrane in this area appears to be excessively
              thin, indicating that either the waterproofing membrane has not
              been properly installed, or not enough coats of material have been
              applied.

Although it is not possible for us to measure the exact thickness
              of the applied waterproofing membrane while it is installed, it
              should not appear thin and bare, with the substrate visible
              underneath.

Part 3.8.1.2 of the NCC's Building Code of Australia (BCA) -
              Wet Areas, states that;

Additionally, the builder warrants that the work will be carried
              out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’
, which is not the case in this area.

These areas must be rectified to be fully waterproofed to protect
              the building elements from damage in accordance with the BCA,
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s requirements, which
              will most likely require additional coats of waterproofing be
              installed.

The wall adjoining the sink, basin, or trough has not been made
              water resistant to a height of 150mm in accordance with the
              Building Code of Australia (BCA) and relevant Australian Standard
              AS 3740 to prevent water leaks into the structure that could cause
              damage.

Part 3.8.1.2 of the Building Code of Australia (NCC/BCA) - Wet
              Areas, states that;

‘Building elements in wet areas within a building
              must-

a) be waterproof or water resistant in accordance with Table
              3.8.1.1; and
b) comply with AS 3740’

Table 3.8.1.1 in the NCC/BCA shows that the wall adjoining the
              vessel must be water resistant to 150mm high, and any penetrations
              that occur in the water resistant surfaces are required to be
              waterproof;

The builder must install a water resistant splashback, such as
              tiling (or similar) to at least 150mm high to the areas adjoining
              the sink, basin, or trough and fully waterproof around any
              penetrations within the 150mm high area, as required by the
              NCC’s Building Code of Australia and Australian Standard AS
              3740.

There has not been waterproofing propely installed to the
              balcony, which may result in water leaking.

Part 3.8.1.3 - External above ground membranes of the NCC’s
              Building Code of Australia requires that

‘Waterproofing membranes for external above ground use must
              comply with AS 4654.1 and AS 4654.2’ .

This balcony will need to be properly waterproofed with the
              correct vertical upward termination height above the finished
              floor height, in accordance with the BCA and AS4654.

The balcony waterproofing has not been properly terminated up the
              walls/vertical surfaces, which may result in water leaking.

Part 3.8.1.3 - External above ground membranes of the NCC’s
              Building Code of Australia requires that

‘Waterproofing membranes for external above ground use must
              comply with AS 4654.1 and AS 4654.2’

, and the relevant Australian Standard AS 4654.2 Waterproofing
              membranes for external above-ground use in Clause 2.8.1 –
              Upward terminations states that

‘Where the membrane is to prevent water entry, the finished
              height of the membrane above the finished surface level shall be
              sufficient to prevent water, including wind driven, flowing over
              the top of the membrane’ .

There are two termination options provided in AS4654.2 for this
              termination detail, see below;

As the current detail may result in future leaking, this balcony
              will need to be properly waterproofed with the correct vertical
              upward termination detail, in accordance with the BCA and
              AS4654.

There are screws installed through the top of the parapet wall in
              this balcony, which may lead to leaking and damage to the building
              elements.

Part 3.8.1.3 - External above ground membranes of the NCC’s
              Building Code of Australia requires that

‘Waterproofing membranes for external above ground use must
              comply with AS 4654.1 and AS 4654.2’

, and the relevant Australian Standard AS 4654.2 Waterproofing
              membranes for external above-ground use is clear that screws must
              not be installed through the parapet, and instead provides a
              detail on how this must be installed, see below;

As the current detail may result in future leaking, this balcony
              will need to be properly rectified by replacing the balcony
              parapet detail in accordance with the BCA and AS4654.

There is a visible hole or leak point in the balcony
              waterproofing system, where water may be able to leak through and
              damage the building elements.

Part 3.8.1.3 - External above ground membranes of the NCC’s
              Building Code of Australia requires that

‘Waterproofing membranes for external above ground use must
              comply with AS 4654.1 and AS 4654.2’

, and the relevant Australian Standard AS 4654.2 Waterproofing
              membranes for external above-ground use requires that the balcony
              be fully waterproofed.

Additionally, the builder warrants that the work will be carried
              out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’
, which is not the case in this area.

These areas must be rectified to be fully waterproofed to protect
              the building elements from damage in accordance with the BCA,
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s requirements.

The balcony posts/screw penetrations do not appear to have been
              properly sealed into the waterproofing system in accordance with
              Australian Standards, with holes around the posts/screws where
              water may leak through and cause damage to the building
              elements.

Part 3.8.1.3 - External above ground membranes of the NCC’s
              Building Code of Australia requires that

‘Waterproofing membranes for external above ground use must
              comply with AS 4654.1 and AS 4654.2’

, and the relevant Australian Standard AS 4654.2 Waterproofing
              membranes for external above-ground use requires that the balcony
              be fully waterproofed.

Additionally, the builder warrants that the work will be carried
              out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’
, which is not the case in this area.

These areas must be rectified to be fully waterproofed to protect
              the building elements from damage in accordance with the BCA,
              Australian Standards and manufacturer’s requirements.

There are visible bows along the skirting line at the bottom of
              the walls where plaster floats are required to make the finished
              surfaces straight.
The builder warrants that the work will be carried out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’

, which is not the case in these areas, and should be floated out
              to be straight prior to works in this area proceeding any
              further.

There are visible bows along the cornice line at the top of the
              walls where plaster floats are required to make the finished
              surfaces straight.
The builder warrants that the work will be carried out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’

, which is not the case in these areas, and should be floated out
              to be straight prior to works in this area proceeding any
              further.

The builder has not installed water resistant plasterboard to
              this area, which is likely to encounter damp conditions.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances states in section 9.11 Plasterboard Sheeting, that

‘The installation and jointing of plasterboard sheeting
              systems is defective if it does not conform to AS/NZS 2589 and the
              manufacturer’s installation instructions’ .

The plasterboard manufacturers all vary in what they require in
              their installation instructions. However, water resistant
              plasterboard is required by all manufacturers where their product
              is likely to see moisture or damp conditions.

The builder should make all areas comply with the BCA, Australian
              Standards, and manufacturer's installation instructions. In
              this case, we recommend that the builder contact the plasterboard
              manufacturer to confirm what product they recommend for this
              specific situation, to ensure the long-term performance of their
              product, and the surrounding building elements.

This door is binding on the floor coverings when in use, making
              it difficult to operate.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 8.07 Operation of windows and doors states that

‘The installation of doors and windows is defective if,
              within three months of completion, they bind or jam as a result of
              the builder’s workmanship, or do not operate as intended by
              the manufacturer’ .

This door should be cut down and repainted, or otherwise adjusted
              so it operates properly without binding.

The skirting board in this area has been installed visibly out of
              level, which looks poorly finished.
The builder warrants that the work will be carried out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’

, which is not the case in this area, and should be rectified or
              replaced prior to handover.

The hebel panel in this area has been cut, exposing the internal
              reinforcing steel inside the panel, which is not sealed and will
              rust over time causing damage and possible failure of the hebel
              panel.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state that

'Reinforcement exposed during cutting must be coated with a
              liberal application of Hebel corrosion protection paint' .

The section drawing below shows the steel reinforcement inside
              the panels;

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The hebel panel in this area has been cut, exposing the internal
              reinforcing steel inside the panel, which is not sealed and will
              rust over time causing damage and possible failure of the hebel
              panel.

The Hebel PowerFloor design and installation instructions state
              that

'Reinforcement exposed during cutting must be coated with a
              liberal application of Hebel corrosion protection paint' .

The section drawing below shows the steel reinforcement inside
              the panels;

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The hebel in this area has a penetration through the panel that
              has not been sealed, which will possibly allow water and pest
              ingress, and will also reduce the thermal and acoustic performance
              of the Hebel panel system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.3 Installation of Services, that

'Penetrations through the PowerPanelXL panel for services
              should be neatly filled and the joint sealed with an external
              grade acoustic and/or fire rated paintable sealant' .

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The builder has not provided a 75mm (minimum) gap under the Hebel
              panels to the ground, which the manufacturer warns will cause
              damage to the Hebel panels.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state that

‘All garden beds and /or finished soil line must remain a
              minimum of 75mm below the bottom of the finished rendered
              wall' .

The ground levels must be immediately rectified to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

There are Hebel wall panels in this area that are overhanging the
              slab by more than 25mm.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state that
‘the maximum panel overhang is 25mm' .

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall panels in this area are in contact with the
              flashings, which will not allow deflection, or moisture and
              condensation from behind the panels to escape, causing damage to
              the Hebel system or other building elements.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions show the following detail for this situation;

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction at the required 6.0m spacing,
              which could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Vertical control joints required at maximum 6m
              centres.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction in the required area above
              and below the door opening, which could cause failure of the
              system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Vertical control joints required above and below all doors,
              including sliding and garage doors.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

itemName: Hebel Wall Control Joint (Horizontal Floor Junction)

children.text:
The Hebel wall system has not been provided with horizontal
              control joints for expansion and contraction at the floor
              junction, which could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Horizontal control joints required at every horizontal floor
              junction.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction to at least one side of this
              window opening, which could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- For openings > 2450mm and < 3600mm wide: Control joint
              required to at least one side of the opening (i.e. above and below
              the opening). If the straight joint that extends above or below
              the window jamb is less than 600mm long a control joint or a glued
              and meshed joint is required to the opposite side of the
              opening.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction to both sides of this wide
              window opening, which could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- For openings > 3600mm in width: Control joint required to
              both sides of the opening (i.e. above and below the
              opening).'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction at the external corner in
              this area, which could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Vertical control joints required at external and internal
              corners.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system has not been provided with vertical control
              joints for expansion and contraction at the internal corner, which
              could cause failure of the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Vertical control joints required at external and internal
              corners.'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel wall system is greater than 3.9m high, and has not been
              provided with horizontal control joints for expansion and
              contraction at the required spacing, which could cause failure of
              the system.

The Hebel Power Panel external wall design and installation
              instructions state in section 3.5.7 Control Joints, that

- Horizontal control joints required at a maximum height of
              3.9m'

This required control joint must be properly installed to prevent
              failure of the Hebel system, prior to works in this area
              proceeding any further.

The Hebel in this area has not been provided with a shrinkage gap
              of at least 10mm under the sill, which will not allow the expected
              movement.

This must be properly rectified to prevent failure of the Hebel
              system, prior to works in this area proceeding any further.
The door hardware in this area is showing signs of rust.
The builder warrants that the work will be carried out in
‘a proper and workmanlike manner’
, and
‘with reasonable care and skill’

, which is not the case in this area, and this door hardware
              should be fully cleaned or replaced prior to handover.

The bottom of the downpipe on the lower roof has not been fitted
              with a spreader.
The NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires that

‘All water discharged from a gutter/valley or downpipe onto
              a tiled roof must be prevented from inundating or penetrating the
              tiling by the provision of a spreader pipe’

. Additionally, the relevant Australian Standard, AS 3500
              Plumbing & Drainage Part 3 – Stormwater, states in
              clause 3.4.5 Higher Catchment Area that

‘Stormwater from a higher catchment area shall be
              discharged direct to an appropriately sized rainhead or sump.
              Alternatively, a spreader, may be used subject to, for a tiled
              roof the lower section being sarked a minimum width of 1800mm,
              either side from the point of discharge, and extended down to the
              eaves gutter’ .

The builder should install a spreader pipe in this area, and
              ensure that the lower roof area has been constructed
              appropriately.

The gas piping is being crossed, or in direct contact with the
              electrical wiring.

The relevant Australian Standard AS 5601 Gas Installation, clause
              5.3.4 Separation from Above-Ground Electrical Equipment states
              that

‘There shall be at least 25mm separation between any
              consumer piping and any above-ground electrical wire or cable not
              in a conduit’.

The electrical wiring and gas pipes need to be separated from
              each other at all locations.

There is a visible hole in the waterproofing membrane, which
              could possibly result in a long-term water leak that can cause
              damage to the structure and surrounding areas.

The NCC’s Building Code of Australia and Australian
              Standard AS 3740 – Waterproofing of domestic wet areas
              requires that these wet areas be waterproofed, therefore the
              builder must repair these holes.
There is a hinge missing on the door in this area.

This missing door hinge should be installed for it to operate as
              intended by the manufacturer.

There are gaps around the external door frame that need to be
              sealed to prevent water and pest ingress.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 8.02 Weather-tightness of windows, doors, and
              window and door frames states that

‘Window frame and door frame installations are defective
              if, due to the builder’s workmanship, they leak or cause
              unhealthy or dangerous conditions, loss of amenity for occupants,
              undue dampness or deterioration of building elements’ .

These gaps must be sealed in accordance with the above
              requirement to avoid water that may leak, or pest ingress that may
              cause unhealthy conditions or damage the building elements.

There are gaps around the external window frame that needs to be
              sealed to prevent water and pest ingress.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 8.02 Weather-tightness of windows, doors, and
              window and door frames states that

‘Window frame and door frame installations are defective
              if, due to the builder’s workmanship, they leak or cause
              unhealthy or dangerous conditions, loss of amenity for occupants,
              undue dampness or deterioration of building elements’ .

These gaps must be sealed in accordance with the above
              requirement to avoid water that may leak, or pest ingress that may
              cause unhealthy conditions or damage the building elements.

The top of the shower wall tiling has not been sealed to the
              wall, allowing water and condensation into the rear of the tiles,
              which may cause delamination.

This item must be rectified to ensure the long-term performance
              of the tile adhesive.
The sink has not been fully sealed to the benchtop.

The Victorian Building Authority’s Guide to Standards and
              Tolerances clause 10.09 Sealing around benches and items installed
              in benches, states that

‘Seals around items such as sinks, hand basins or the like
              are defective if the joint leaks or they are not installed in
              accordance with the manufacturer’s installation
              requirements’ .

These gaps must be sealed in accordance with the above
              requirement to avoid water that may leak and damage the joinery or
              other building elements.
